awd_titl_txt: NeTS: Small: Sketching Big Network Data
awd_abstract_narration:
Sketches are compact data structures maintained in network switches that store the summary of network data flows and permit answering queries with estimated results.  This project aims to develop new virtual sketching methods that reduce big network data to measurement summaries orders-of-magnitude smaller than what the traditional sketches can do.  The new methods hold the promise of allowing routers to perform measurement on large network traffic at line speed, allowing enterprise systems to keep their network data records for much longer time, and allowing users with ordinary computing resources to work on big network data.

A major research thrust in sketches is to reduce their memory footprint. Virtual sketches permit different flows to share a common pool of memory.
Space sharing can drastically reduce the memory requirement, but this sharing introduces noise. Fortunately, we find that for randomized sharing schemes, the noise can be statistically measured and removed.  This project will investigate (1) a theoretical study on new methods of space sharing, (2) common procedures for highly efficient online operations on virtual sketches with low overhead, (3) spatial virtual sketches for joint measurement of network data at different routers, (4) temporal virtual sketches for joint measurement of network data across different time periods, and (5) virtual composite sketches for sophisticated network data measurement.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed to develop new sketching methods that reduced big network data to measurement summaries orders-of-magnitude smaller than what the traditional sketches could do. The new methods held the promise of allowing routers to perform measurement on large network traffic at line speed, allowing enterprise systems to keep their network data records for much longer time, and allowing users with ordinary computing resources to work on big network data.

Sketches are compact data structures that store the summary of a large data set and answer queries with estimated results. A major research thrust in sketches is to reduce their memory footprint. After decades of improvement, the traditional way of sketching appeared to reach its limit, e.g., requiring hundreds of bits per data flow for cardinality estimation. This project set an ambitious goal of further reducing average space requirement by orders of magnitude to 1 bit or even 0.1 bit per flow. To achieve this goal, we took a non-conventional approach based on a new concept called virtual sketches. We still allocated (virtual) sketches to each data flow. However, the sketches of different flows shared a common pool of memory. Space sharing could drastically reduce the memory requirement, but when we wrote information to the sketches of one flow, it introduced noise to the measurement of other flows through shared data structures. Fortunately, we found that for randomized sharing schemes, the noise could be statistically measured and removed.

The project advanced the knowledge of designing and analyzing virtualized data structures that were used to summarize large network traffic streams. Starting from memory-sharing sketches, the research branched out in multiple dimensions into the depth of a large research space: new space sharing methods, virtualization of sophisticated sketches, common virtualized designs of online operations, spatial virtual sketches, temporal virtual sketches, and composite virtual sketches. The outcome of the project not only provided new designs and software tools for processing big network data with unprecedented resource efficiency, but also laid the theoretical foundation and performance benchmarks for future studies on space-sharing virtualized data structures.

Virtual sketches proposed in this project have great potential in improving the capability of modern routers, firewalls, enterprise systems, and end users to process big network data with ordinary computing resources. Moreover, because the basic data structures and their functions embodied in virtual sketches are widely applicable in Computer Science, improvement in their performance can have broad impact in other research and application fields. The research results from this project were disseminated through conference/journal publications as well as the project website. The education part of the project included new course creation (Internet Data Streaming), undergraduate participation, and recruitment of under-represented minorities.

 


Last Modified: 01/24/2022
Modified by: Shigang Chen
